prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

para.paratext: Just as the factors that favor transfer are difficult to isolate and assess with precision, it is impossible to weigh precisely the factors that may convince the Panel that transfer is not appropriate. These factors are very important to a party opposing transfer, however. Although there certainly are dockets where transfer is all but inevitable, in others there may be compelling arguments that can be marshaled against transfer. Those factors are analyzed in the following sections.

One obvious factor-so obvious we have not included a separate analysis of it-is the absence of the factors that favor transfer. That fact a docket comprises few actions militates against transfer, and is more or less subsumed in the factors analyzed here. For example, there is little doubt that it is easier to manage a small number of actions without transfer.[1]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
